text: this is Steven Farrell for the New York
Times in Cairo on a day of political
maneuverings in Cairo protesters trying
to overthrow the Egyptian government
found themselves rimmed by a much
heavier to presence than usual Saturday
in a sign of perhaps growing official
impatience at having central Cairo shut
down for two weeks the army rigged
Tahrir Square with reservoir and
helmeted soldiers unmistakeably
prominent was an armored bulldozer
easily capable of demolishing the
protesters flimsy barricades it was the
opening move in what appeared to be more
aggressive yet carefully calibrated show
of force on a day when some of the
regime's key Western backers appeared to
be leaning toward a gradual transition
in Egypt rather than the immediate how
sting of President Hosni Mubarak first
came words Brigadier General Hassan
rouhani climbed atop a car to address
the anti-mubarak demonstrators it was
time to put the city back to work he
said through a megaphone and to clear
away the damage he engaged the
protesters there was empathy an
avuncular hug but also a flash of
authority when one woman used the
microphone to lead the crowd into
anti-mubarak slogans and then suddenly
the general was off he in a handful of
men breaking through the barricades and
down the road beside the Egypt museum
toward Tahrir Square itself what
followed was an owl on melee through the
crown the general alternately engaging
protesters and throwing down obstacles
as he moved through the square asked
what his men use force he ruled that out
again with the tone of a stern parent
losing patience with unruly children
officer Hoggatt Aslam ever met
and then he was off again plowing
through crowds tents anything in his
path it seemed part overture part
reconnaissance mission part serving
notice the crowds were confused rather
than angry but showed no sign of
moderating their demands he must go we
won't go they chanted of Mubarak which
leaves everyone back where they started
feet apart on the ground miles apart
politically
